newsitem.title: JAPAN: TOCOM precious metals end lower as yen firms.
newsitem.headline: TOCOM precious metals end lower as yen firms.

text.p: Yen-based Tokyo precious metal futures ended weaker on Thursday on light volume, pressured by the yen's firmer tendency against the dollar, traders said.
Gold prices ranged from flat to nine yen per gram lower. Most-active benchmark April was down two at 1,370 yen.
Traders said they were tending to be moderately bearish on yen-based gold futures.
"Gold futures may have more room to dip, as the yen's firmness dampened market sentiment," one trader said.
Spot gold was quoted at $342.40/70 per ounce at 0734 GMT, against $341.00/50 in New York on Wednesday.
In the bullion market, moderate two-way trade was detected.
One trader said he expected gold to drift within a tight range of between $340 and $343 per ounce, due to a lack of fresh incentives to move gold either way.
Platinum and palladium futures were mostly lower.
News on Wednesday that Russia may have signed a long-awaited decree to resume exports of platinum group metals (PGM) halted since December, had little impact on the market.
The market remains wary because the Russian PGM export agency has not informed Japanese buyers of an exact time schedule for export contract talks in Japan, a trader said.
Mixed trade was detected in platinum group metals.
"In palladium futures, some private investors covered shorts on price dips, while others built fresh shorts on believing prices may fall once Russia resumes exports," a palladium trader said.
Palladium prices ranged from four yen to eight yen per gram lower. Benchmark April was off four yen at 596 yen.
Platinum futures ranged from flat to seven yen per gram lower, with benchmark April ending down one yen at 1,464 yen.
Benchmark April silver was down 0.3 yen per 10 grams at 192.7 yen.
